text: [Music]
it's still too early to know whether
Dubai is a bit of a oneoff or the start
of a of a larger Trend what I what I
think it is symptomatic of though is a
trend towards a more deflationary
politics in an
inflationary political world we believe
that everybody is in the same boat and
everybody needs to be bailed out because
um everybody could have been in the same
boat um but for the grace of God in a
deflationary world we say that some
people are good people and some people
are bad people and we do not um give the
bad people more money whether they're
made off or people who lied on their
subprime mortgage applications and I
think the trend has been relentlessly
from an inflationary to a deflationary
political regime where we think of um
where we no longer think of everybody
being the same boat but we think of
there being good good people and bad
people with respect to Dubai the basic
uh the basic mistake people made was
they assumed that it was um all part of
the United Arab Emirates everybody was
in the same boat Abu Dhabi had lots of
money and they would help Dubai out in
reality Abu Dhabi was probably quite
resentful of the uh shiny and glittering
and fake uh city known as Dubai and uh
and when push came to shove didn't
really want to give them more money and
I think that kind of a um emotional or
political or social phenomenon is going
to be much more widespread and the the
question that will come to the for in
the next few years is Will Germany bail
out Greece or Spain or Italy or Eastern
Europe will the um responsible people
bail out those they deem to be less
responsible if General Motors goes
bankrupt again will it get a second
bailout will there be a second bailout
for the banks will there be a second
stimulus bill I think the answer to all
of these things is no so if the crisis
is not
over um then um if it comes back it will
come back in a very different political
form and there will be much less
tolerance the second time around just to
use the stimulus as one example if the
first stimulus worked you don't need a
second one if the first stimulus did not
work um it's hard to see why a second
one would work either way very hard to
get a second stimulus and so um The View
that we will just constantly stimulate
we will constantly bail people out I
think is very misguided and I think it
underestimates the degree to which we've
shifted from an inflationary mindset
that it's booms bubbles busts we're all
in the same boat to a deflationary
mindset of um uh separating good people
from bad people and punishing bad people
I personally think there's some truth to
both stories um but I I merely observe
that we are we're relentlessly drifting
uh towards a deflationary political
world
h
